Apartment-

Maintenance-

I had many issues, but two major ones stand out:

- Electrical problem:
The kitchen circuit shorted, causing three outlets (including the fridge) to stop working. I submitted a service request and maintenance came the next day. I told them it was probably a breaker issue, but they kept replacing outlets instead of checking the fuse box. They ended up wasting an entire day trying random fixes before finally sending someone the next day who confirmed ‚Äî it was the breaker. Exactly what I said from the start.

- No heat during winter:
My heat went out during the coldest week of the season. The maintenance guy literally said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm doing,‚Äù and left me with two small space heaters. I went five days without proper heat. Completely unacceptable and shows how unqualified their team is.

Insect Control -

If you like insects, you‚Äôll feel right at home here. I lived on the basement floor, and during summer, hundreds of beetles gathered outside my bedroom window ‚Äî and eventually started finding their way inside.
I tried calling the office‚Ä¶ surprise ‚Äî no one picked up (which became a theme). On top of that, there were spiders and worms throughout the apartment. It‚Äôs clear they don‚Äôt have any kind of pest control plan in place.

Leasing Office -

Easily the worst communication I‚Äôve ever experienced from a management team. They never answer the phone ‚Äî and I mean never.

One time, they decided to rekey the building doors and sent the new keys in envelopes. I never received mine. I tried calling over and over again, no response. I eventually had to go through Trowbridge just to get someone from Hidden Valley to talk to me. Their excuse was, ‚ÄúWe were on a tour.‚Äù Either they‚Äôre severely understaffed or just don‚Äôt care.

This wasn‚Äôt a one-time thing ‚Äî every time I needed to contact them, it was the same story. No one picks up, no one calls back.

Conclusion -

If you‚Äôre moving to Ann Arbor, please look elsewhere. You‚Äôll save yourself a lot of stress and frustration. The only good thing about this place is the location ‚Äî that‚Äôs it.

Don‚Äôt be fooled by management‚Äôs cookie-cutter replies or excuses to my post ‚Äî they don‚Äôt reflect the real experience. Spend a little more for a better-managed and better-maintained apartment. It‚Äôll be worth it in the long run.

I have had a very negative experience living at Pine Valley for almost 4 years, and I don‚Äôt recommend it to anyone. Their infrastructure, grounds, and buildings are kept in poor condition, and their maintenance staff is awful. This has resulted in numerous problems for me over the years, one of which (my car being flooded in my assigned parked space in their parking lot) cost me tens of thousands of dollars.

The storm drains at my complex were blocked, causing the parking lot to flood during a summer storm (see photo). My car was totaled and I had to buy a new one. After months of stress, emails, not being able to get to work, etc and tens of thousands of dollars in damages due to their bad infrastructure, Pine Valley ultimately gave me $0 in compensation.

The buildings are in poor shape in general, and maintenance is shoddy. I have been dealing with ants coming in through vents and windows/cracks in the foundation throughout my 4 years here, including carpenter ants which live in rotting wood (see photo). Maintenance is a joke‚ÄîI once had them unclog my shower drain (regular need due to the old narrow pipes), and they LEFT all the gray sludge from the pipes sitting in my tub and sprayed around my bathroom where my cat could get into it (see photo). Many of the ‚Äúrepairs‚Äù they‚Äôve done have been useless ‚Äì they had to fix the door closer on the door leading into my apartment, and it looked like it was done by a 4 year old with a screwdriver (see photo; it obviously broke again a few days later). They also had to replace electrical breakers, and they tore up my drywall in the process and just left giant holes in the wall (see photo); I emailed them about the issue, and they simply never responded. They also illegally issue blanket notices of entry for ‚Äúsome time over these 5 days‚Äù (see photo for example), so you actually have no idea when contractors, inspectors, etc are going to be coming into your home.

They have a new resident manager every 6-12 months (high turnover never a good sign...) so you‚Äôre constantly dealing with someone new who doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on. Also, although this isn‚Äôt their fault, they are located in the part of Ann Arbor that has the most frequent and longest lasting DTE power outages, so if you live here you have to be prepared for multi-day stretches without power during winter storms.

I could honestly keep sharing details and photos of even more bad experiences, but I think the image is clear. Rent somewhere else. I‚Äôm looking forward to moving elsewhere this summer.

I was a resident at Pine Valley Apartments from 2019 to 2023. In 2019, they had a pretty nice set of office staff. They hosted an annual "resident appreciation week" where they offered free food and raffles for prizes. My roommate and I won a 50in 4K TV, which was great. However, these resident appreciation weeks halted around 2022 for unknown reasons. While living at Pine Valley got off to a great start, it gradually worsened each year. The turnover for office and maintenance staff was incredibly high. I counted about 6 residential managers between 2019 and 2023, all of whom left abruptly. In 2023, they hired a new manager named Kelly. She seemed fine at first, but I quickly changed my mind. I had intended to vacate my apartment but had to cancel this plan at the last second because my plans fell through. Kelly was angry that I cancelled. So she lied, saying the apartment had already been leased to someone else. She attempted to illegally evict my roommate and me from our home, threatening to send lawyers and police to force us out of the apartment. I had never encountered someone so cold before.

Despite Kelly's bosses knowing what she had done, they did not fire her. Kelly continued her behavior, but it was now directed at all residents. Pine Valley had been in non-compliance with the city of Ann Arbor for nearly a year, and Kelly decided to hang signs on the buildings threatening to pass the city fines Pine Valley received onto the residents if they refused to allow city inspectors or maintenance personnel to enter their homes. My apartment, in particular, needed its tub reglazed (something many other apartments also needed). However, my bathtub was chipped and in need of reglazing the day I arrived in my apartment in 2019.

They had ample opportunities to address these problems each time there was resident turnover, for instance, they could have reglazed my tub before I moved in. Therefore, it's preposterous for Pine Valley and Kelly to attempt shifting the blame and consequences of non-compliance onto the residents. Many of the reasons for the non-compliance were due to issues that had been neglected for years. Pine Valley has no one to blame but themselves for their non-compliance. And yes, this means they have to accept the consequences of their greed and neglect. Perhaps they could hang signs on the buildings that say "We are sorry for neglecting these buildings for many years and not fixing things before you moved in. We want to change that now, so please help us do that." Rather, this is how they acted in a nutshell: "Let us fix your homes now that the city inspectors are onto us. If you don't let us in now, we will fine you. How dare you disrespect us." Hypocrisy at its finest.

I could touch on many other issues, such as how the pool wasn't being cared for anymore as it was filthy most of the time. Conveniently, they would close the pool when the city inspectors came, then reopen it when they left. Or I could mention how the apartment would heat up very easily and it was usually very humid and stuffy inside even with the A/C on or windows open. They did not consider spraying for wasp nests or yellow jacket nests on the buildings or by the pool, so there were a ton of wasps and yellow jackets near the pool or near our balcony. It's common courtesy to monitor wasp/yellow jacket nests to protect residents from being stung. I could never fully enjoy sitting on my balcony with all the wasps flying around. We even had wasps get inside, likely through a crack in our sliding door.

The only positives I can provide are: the rent is somewhat affordable compared to other places in Ann Arbor, the nearby neighborhood is nice, they offer month-to-month leases, and I liked how much closet space we had. However, personally, these positives do not compensate for the major issues I witnessed.

All in all, I do not recommend living at Pine Valley. Unless they learn to treat residents with as much respect as they demand, I don't foresee any improvement at Pine Valley.

TL;DR: Manchester Flats offers cute, affordable, and well-located apartments, but McKinley‚Äôs management enforces questionable policies‚Äîespecially a problematic bed bug lease addendum‚Äîand exhibits harassing behavior that may violate state law. Proceed with caution and read the lease carefully.

Manchester Flats apartments have a lot going for them: they‚Äôre on the bus line, close to downtown, and relatively affordable for Ann Arbor‚Äîespecially for those on PhD stipends or a tight budget. The hardwood floors and abundant sunlight are definite pluses. The buildings are old and have minor maintenance issues, but nothing major.

The real downside is McKinley‚Äôs management.

In 2025, they introduced a Bed Bug Lease Addendum with two alarming clauses:
1. They could evict tenants within seven days if bed bugs were found.
2. If they determined the tenant was responsible, they could hold the tenant financially liable for all treatment costs, including those for adjoining units.

I had bed bugs during my tenancy (not the only unit affected) and did everything possible to address the issue, including buying a new mattress and deep cleaning. I support policies that require tenants and landlords to promptly and thoroughly address bed bug issues.

However, the landlord‚Äôs powers in this addendum‚Äîeven if aimed at non-cooperative tenants‚Äîare alarming. My lawyer advised that these terms may violate Michigan state law. When I raised these concerns, management dismissed them, saying the addendum would apply to all their properties and would not be changed for one tenant.

I had fully intended to resign another year, but given the recent nature of my bed bug experience, I couldn't rationally agree to all these new addendum terms.

After I gave notice not to renew, management‚Äôs behavior devolved further:
* They responded to my non-renewal notice with a single ‚Äútada‚Äù/"party popper" üéâ emoji (an attempt to celebrate my departure amongst themselves discreetly? They quietly tried to remove it later, but - unfortunately for them - such reactions leave an electronic paper trail)
* They immediately misrepresented lease terms and threatened me with improper holdover charges. (I didn‚Äôt hold over the apartment - I left early, nearly two weeks early before the lease ended)
* They refused to accept my written non-renewal notice unless I used their official forms (not required by the lease).
* When I turned in my keys a week early, they tried to enforce an undocumented policy against accepting them early (but eventually did).

These behaviors greatly overshadowed what had been an overall 5/5 experience. But I cannot recommend living here with this specific management in control.

If you‚Äôre considering signing a lease here, don‚Äôt. But if you must, READ IT CAREFULLY‚Äîespecially the bed bug addendum. And be prepared to deal with management behaviors like the ones I described - or worse.
